turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Tell me about them, Thea. They have great wings end long teeth --

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Sharp, shiny teeth -- and they creep up to your bed --

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Closer and closer - until they bite into your throat!

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: My father -- I'm alone, Oliver, completely alone!

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Poor Cathy --

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Last night Dr. Drossos -- today you or I -- oh, no, Oliver, it can't be you, I couldn't stand it.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: There's no reason to decide any of us are going to die.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: If only we could get away - - you and I. The others are strangers, they mean nothing to me

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: If Mr. Albrecht is right, we'll all be free in a few days.  I suppose you'll be going on to Athens?

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: I don't know now without my father.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Poor child. These must be horrible days for you.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: I'm so ill, I'm so exhausted -- I almost don't care.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Has that girl -- has Thea ever told you where she comes from?

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Some village in the mountains -- Alethera, I think.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Has she spoken to you of her father and her mother?

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: She has never mentioned her family.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: How old is she?

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: I was looking for you.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: I have been troubled about you. I want you to know that my room is just downstairs --  You have only to cry out if you are ill  or frightened.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: How kind you are. It is so comforting to know that someone cares.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Miss Wollsten shares the room with you?

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: No, that's Thea's bed. Miss Wollsten's bed is in there.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: It's getting dark. I can't leave now.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: In the morning -- go. I'll not die until then - I'll not die  I'll watch - they shall not hurt you.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Shh it's all right - I'll be all right.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: They shall not hurt you

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: The young man, Mr. Davis, seems to be some kind of an unofficial observer  a correspondent of some sort 

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: And the soldier -- He looked at me so strangely -- who is he?

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: You are fortunate in your father.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Thea is an orphan.

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: Cathy - how does it feel to have a father?

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: What an odd question!

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: I mean, does one love a father because he is good and kind -or just because he is one's father?

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Why, I love my father because - because I do. Of course, he's nice to me.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Thea -- you're hiding something. Why do you suddenly speak of your father? You told me once you had never seen him -- didn't know him --

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: I do not know him, but I have seen him.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: What is it -- what are you talking about?

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: You have forgotten my last name?

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: I have forgotten it, dear.

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: My last name is Pherides.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Thea, your choice is a very simple one. Either you want to claim him as your father, or you do not.

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: But one must love a father.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: The General  you don't even know him.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Come, Thea, if you're going to claim him as your father you've got to make up your mind. They'll be leaving any minute.

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: I don't know. As a child. I longed for a father and now - I don't know 

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: I felt he did not like me.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: That should decide it or you --

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: I will let him go. He is dead to me as he is to all my mother's people. I turn my hand against him.

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: You should sleep, Cathy. Lie down and close your eyes. Try to forget everything.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: When I close my eyes, I see Miss Wollsten. I can't think of anything else.

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: She is dead  at peace.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Suppose, she isn't dead. Suppose it was a cataleptic attack?

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: It was, the plague

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: We quarreled. She never dared get angry or frightened -- but I said things to her -- it was an attack, I know it was.

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: I wish I didn't have such bitter knowledge of you, Cathy.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Whet do you mean?

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: They were talking about the Vrykolakas this morning. Cathy, that's what you are  a weak, pale, half-dead thing that drains all the life and joy from those who want to live.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Miss Wollsten!

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: You and your mysterious illness. A new attack everytime you are crossed  everytime you can't get your own way.

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: Your father knew it too. But he was never sure how much was pretense.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: How do you know what my father thought - -

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: Your father loved me.  He wanted to marry me. But he was afraid of hurting the gentle, delicate Cathy. You spoiled his life you've ruined mine 

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: You were father's secretary - I never thought - -

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: Didn't you? But now -- what are you thinking now?

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: What would I be thinking?

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: Mr. Davis seems a good prospect young handsome, sympathetic -- ready to listen to you and feel sorry for you - -

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: What if he is?

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: ) But Thea -- She stands in your way. I know you. I know your little hints  the way you can turn the truth into a lie --

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Why, I'm fond of Thea.

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: You're planing something, Cathy.. But I won't let you - I'll warn them against you.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: You will not say one single word. I know your secret.

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: That your father and I 

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: No. I mean your other secret -	the one you kept bidden even from my father. That old doctor in London -- he told me.

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: I've always known what an evil mind lay behind that pretty weak face of yours  but this, Cathy -- even I would never have believed it is of you.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Would you care to explain what you're talking about?

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: You've been playing on the superstitions of that poor old man   working at him   turning him against Thea.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Really, this is idiotic!

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: You'd do anything to get Oliver away from Thea. But I'm going to stop you. I'm going to tell Mr. Davis exactly what you are.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: When I tell him that you're unfit to live a normal life with normal people - a cataleptic!

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: You wouldn't tell that 

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Wouldn't I?

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: No. No. I won't believe it. He's not dead.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: This is Dr. Drossos, chief medical officer of my division.

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: I don't care who he is. He doesn't know.	He can't tell 

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Woman, what are you doing here?

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: I wanted to be sure of something, General -- something that has always preyed on my mind. I have a horror of being buried alive and awakening to find myself shut in - entombed  imprisoned..

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: He sleeps quietly. He died with a wine glass in his hand -- he died laughing -- a brave man, Drossos, like his father before him.

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: Because he was a brave man - because I liked him -- I came here to be sure.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: He's dead enough. God rest his soul.

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: I'm a woman -- a lonely woman. I have few friends.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: I have not had a happy life --but that one thing - - that terror which brings me awake out of deep sleep - I want to avoid it.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: I don't understand you.

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: I don't want to be buried alive. If I die I want to be sure - quite sure.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: If you should fall sick we'll be careful. You need not worry.

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: No, I want more than that. I beg you General, make sure --drive a knife through my heart -- anything.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: You ask that of me? You're afraid to live in your coffin. You know what that means?

turns.speaker: MISS WOLLSTEN
turns.text: That's superstition. That's something out of old tales -- about the dead who live - I'm talking of something else --cataleptic attacks -- apparent death that is not real.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Never fear -- when you are dead you will remain dead. I will see to it that you do not walk about again. I promise you that. There is another one here who can not die. I will watch you both. Never fear.

turns.speaker: ST. AUBYN
turns.text: I don't really know where Thea comes from. The ViceConsul at Adrianople brought her to me..

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Her name is Thea?

turns.speaker: ST. AUBYN
turns.text: Theodosia.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Her family name?

turns.speaker: ST. AUBYN
turns.text: Damn me, if I know. She's become so much a member of our household I never think of her by any name but Thea -- she has a last name --

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: You do not know her last name -- you do not know from where she came?

turns.speaker: ST. AUBYN
turns.text: Miss Wollsten - my secretary, she'd know.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Your daughter is ill.

turns.speaker: ST. AUBYN
turns.text: She's not too well.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: What is her illness?

turns.speaker: ST. AUBYN
turns.text: Nothing, really. She's been under a great strain -- the journey -- the battle --

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Was she ill before that girl came into your household?

turns.speaker: ST. AUBYN
turns.text: Why -- no not before Thea came 

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: This girl --

turns.speaker: ST. AUBYN
turns.text: This girl -- Thea - is not a servant in my household, sir. She is my daughter's companion. Now, sir, if you'll excuse me, I'll go have a look at Mr. Jacks.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: I will go with you.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Why not Take the doctor's advice? You're the hero of the battle of Corphon.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Hero?

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: In the New York Morning Globe, the man who wins victory is always a hero. -

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: You know that sound, Oliver?

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: I heard the same sound at Ladysmith, at Nukden, Port Arthur.  What do you expect after a battle?

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: You were at those battles as a spectator   I wonder if you can think what that sound might mean to me  those men out there  dead or dying  by my order -- because I willed it so.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Do you mind if I go with you?

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: There's no one there - nothing but the caves and the dead.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: I'll only go as far as the shore and wait for you.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: She is not there. The coffin is gone.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Maybe you've got the wrong crypt  after all it's twenty years when you wore last here.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: You are a happy man Oliver. You have but one world to live in - the world of today. I have two worlds. I have that old dark world of peasant ignorance and superstition in which I was brought up and a new world which the army gave me  a world of mathematics, gun ranges,logistics, tactics, strategy.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: It doesn't seem to bother you much, General.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: I will be glad to leave this island. It has too much of that old dark world about it. I will be glad to leave it and that girl 

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Thea?

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: There is something evil about her.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Oh, now  now look here 

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: I know all you are going to say -I have been saying it to myself, but the thought will not leave my mind. She resembles my wife -there is something about her the way she moves  the way she turns her head.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: But that should make you like her.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: It makes me fear her.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: I can't understand that.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: It is not necessary to understand. We are leaving and I am thankful.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Well, at any rate, I would like to say goodbye to the girl.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: We have no time for that.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: I've seen men die drunk - and I've seen men die of the plague.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Plague? There's no possibility of that, is there?

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: The rider on the pale horse is Pestilence. He follows the wars.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Until we know, what choice is there? We have to stay.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: But the war, the army  they need you.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Better no general than one carrying the plague.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: We still don't know that it's the plague 

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Dr. Drossos will tell us. We will know what to do then.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Thea is so like her  in every feature 

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: If she looked like Thea, she must have been beautiful.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: She was beautiful. There was blood between her family and my kin. But that did not stop me from taking her when I saw her beauty, nor did it stop her from loving me.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: How did she die?

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: I don' t know. When I was gone the people from her village came to my home seeking vengeance. They bore her away with them. Months later she came back pale -- sick -- she died --

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Is this what you wanted to speak to me about?

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: In a way -- this girl, Thea. You must stay away from her.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: I had a notion you had become selfappointed chaperone lately  why?

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: You are my friend.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: And I'm your friend  but that doesn't explain why you are always trying to come between Thea and me?

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: If I told you  you wouldn't believe me -- but this much I can tell you  the girl is dangerous to you. Take a friend's advice -- an old man' s advice -- leave her alone -

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: That's ridiculous -- Thea's lovely, gentle -

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Listen to what I say --

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: When you make sense I'll listen.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: I have had command for the last time -

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Come - you'll feel yourself again as soon as we get off this dismal island.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: I shall not leave the island 

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Theodosia --

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Not Theodosia. Theodosia's daughter -- your daughter.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Daughter -- my daughter --

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: She was born before your wife returned here to die. You never knew.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: You're crying. Why?

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: I don't know. Everything's so mixed up --

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Everything's so simple. I like you.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: What's bothering you, Thea? Is it the General?

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: Sometimes when he looks at me in that strange way, I'm afraid of him.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Don't let it trouble you. He's an old man and these last few days have been a terrible strain on him. He won't harm you.

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: Please.. You shouldn't laugh --

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: You see? Thea believes it, too!

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Thea, what's wrong?

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: The General threatened me.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Oh, that Vrykolaka business. You mustn't be too angry with him, Thea. He's an old man and now with all this trouble  the disappointment in not being able to lead his own army to victory -- cooped up here waiting for death - naturally his mind goes back to the things he believed when he was an ignorant lad in some mountain village.

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: He keeps asking for the name of my father and mother.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Well, tell, him.

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: I can't.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Why in the world can't you?

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: He hates all my race.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: I knew that feuds still went on, but I didn't think people like you and the General would be involved.

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: It is more than a feud between two families. He stole my mother away from her people.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Thea, what is this? What are you trying to tell me? "He stole your mother" -

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: It is for that he hates me.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: I don't think so, Thea. He has spoken of your mother. I don't believe he knows you are his daughter.

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: Then why does he persecute me? My family told me what kind of man he is, how he stole my mother and then abandoned her --

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Because she loved him.  I know him, Thea. Believe me, he is not a cruel man.

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: For a moment, when he looked at me so sadly, I felt that I had wronged him. But then --

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Let me tell him. When he knows you are his child, he'll forget these insane notions -

turns.speaker: THEA
turns.text: No -- you musn't. He thinks I've bewitched you. He won't believe it - he'll hate me even more! My only chance is to stay away from him.

turns.speaker: BAILEY
turns.text: I'm not crying, Mr. Potter.

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: Well, you're begging, and that's a whole lot worse.

turns.speaker: BAILEY
turns.text: All I'm asking is thirty days more . . .

turns.speaker: BAILEY
turns.text: Times are bad, Mr. Potter. A lot of these people are out of work.

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: Then foreclose!

turns.speaker: BAILEY
turns.text: I can't do that. These families have children.

turns.speaker: BAILEY
turns.text: But they're somebody's children.

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: Are you running a business or a charity ward?

turns.speaker: BAILEY
turns.text: Well, all right . . .

turns.speaker: BAILEY
turns.text: Mr. Potter, what makes you such a hard-skulled character? You have no family  no children. You can't begin to spend all the money you've got.

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: So I suppose I should give it to miserable failures like you and that idiot brother of yours to spend for me.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Hey, this is the company's posters, and the company won't like this.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: How would you like to get a ticket next week? Haven't you any romance in you?

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Sure I have, but I got rid of it.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Come on, we got to get this up. He's coming.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: The groom, idiot. Come on, get that ladder.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Get that ladder up here.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: All right  all right.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Hurry up . . . hurry up . . . hurry up.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: I'm hurrying.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: George . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Ernie, I'm a rich tourist today. How about driving me home in style?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: All right, put up your hands. No fast moves. Come on out here, both of you.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Bert! Thank heaven you're here!

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Stand back.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Bert, what's happened to this house? Where's Mary? Where's my kids?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Bert, now listen to me. Ernie, will you take me over to my mother's house? Bert, listen!  It's that fellow there  he says he's an angel  he's tried to hypnotize me.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: I hate to do this, fella.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: What the Sam Hill you yelling for, George?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Don't . . . George?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Know you? Are you kiddin'? I've been looking all over town trying to find you. I saw your car piled into that tree down there, and I thought maybe . . . Hey, your mouth's bleeding; are you sure you're all right?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What did . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Good morning, sir.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Carter  bank examiner.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Mr. Carter, Merry Christmas.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Merry Christmas.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: We're all excited around here.  My brother just got the Congressional Medal of Honor. The President just decorated him.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Well, I guess they do those things. Well, I trust you had a good year.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Good year? Well, between you and me, Mr. Carter, we're broke.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Yeah, very funny.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well . . .  . . . now, come right in here, Mr. Carter.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You what? To save me?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Well, I did, didn't I? You didn't go through with it, did you?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Go through with what?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Suicide.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Oh, I know all about you. I've watched you grow up from a little boy.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What are you, a mind reader or something?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Oh, no.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, who are you, then?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Clarence Odbody, A-S-2.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Odbody . . . A-S-2. What's that A-S-2?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Angel, Second Class.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: That's what I was sent down for. I'm your guardian angel.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I wouldn't be a bit surprised.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Ridiculous of you to think of killing yourself for money. Eight thousand dollars.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I told you  I'm your guardian angel. I know everything about you.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, you look about like the kind of an angel I'd get. Sort of a fallen angel, aren't you? What happened to your wings?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I haven't won my wings yet. That's why I'm an angel Second Class.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I don't know whether I like it very much being seen around with an angel without any wings.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Oh, I've got to earn them, and you'll help me, won't you?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: By letting me help you.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Only one way you can help me. You don't happen to have eight thousand bucks on you?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Oh, no, no. We don't use money in Heaven.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, that's right, I keep forgetting. Comes in pretty handy down here, bub.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Oh, tut, tut, tut.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I found it out a little late. I'm worth more dead than alive.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Now look, you mustn't talk like that. I won't get my wings with that attitude. You just don't know all that you've done. If it hadn't been for you . . .

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: What'd you say?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I said I wish I'd never been born.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Oh, you mustn't say things like that. You . . .  . . . wait a minute. Wait a minute. That's an idea.  What do you think? Yeah, that'll do it. All right.  You've got your wish. You've never been born.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What did you say?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: You've never been born. You don't exist. You haven't a care in the world.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, that's the doggonedest thing . . . I haven't heard anything out of that ear since I was a kid. Must have been that jump in the cold water.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Your lip's stopped bleeding, too, George.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: It's stopped snowing out, hasn't it? What's happened here?  Come on, soon as these clothes of ours are dry . . .

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Our clothes are dry.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I can't fly. I haven't got any wings.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You haven't got your wings. Yeah, that's right.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: You have no car.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, I had a car, and it was right here. I guess somebody moved it.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, I don't know. Either I'm off my nut, or he is . . .  . . . or you are!

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: It isn't me!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, maybe I left the car up at Martini's. Well, come on, Gabriel.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What's the matter with him. I never saw Nick act like that before.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: You'll see a lot of strange things from now on.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, yeah. Hey, little fellow  you worry me. You got someplace to sleep?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You don't huh? Well, you got any money?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No wonder you jumped in the river.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I jumped in the river to save you so I could get my wings.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Oh-oh. Somebody's just made it.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Made what?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Every time you hear a bell ring, it means that some angel's just got his wings.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Look, I think maybe you better not mention getting your wings around here.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Why? Don't they believe in angels?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: You see, George, you were not there to stop Gower from putting that poison into the . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What do you mean, I wasn't there? I remember distinctly . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, I know. You told me that. What else are you? What . . . are you a hypnotist?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: No, of course not.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well then, why am I seeing all these strange things?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Don't you understand, George? It's because you were not born.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Then if I wasn't born, who am I?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: You're nobody. You have no identity.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What do you mean, no identity? My name's George Bailey.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: There is no George Bailey. You have no papers, no cards, no driver's license, no 4-F card, no insurance policy . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Zuzu's petals.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: You know where he lives?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Sure I know where he lives. He lives in Bailey Park.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Are you sure this is Bailey Park?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, I'm not sure of anything anymore. All I know is this should be Bailey Park. But where are the houses?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Clarence . . .

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Yes, George?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Where's Mary?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Oh, well, I can't . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I don't know how you know these things, but tell me  where is she?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: If you know where she is, tell me where my wife is.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I'm not supposed to tell.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: She's . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Where is she?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: Poor George . . . Sit down.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Sit down? What are . . .

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: If you're going to help a man, you want to know something about him, don't you?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Well, naturally. Of course.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: Well, keep your eyes open. See the town?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Where? I don't see a thing.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: Oh, I forgot. You haven't got your wings yet. Now look, I'll help you out. Concentrate. Begin to see something?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Why, yes. This is amazing.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: If you ever get your wings, you'll see all by yourself.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Oh, wonderful!

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Hey, who's that?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: That's your problem, George Bailey.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: A boy?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: That's him when he was twelve, back in 1919. Something happens here you'll have to remember later on.
